title: 108_s2646
content: The Act is titled the "John H. Chafee Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor Sustainability Report Act". It includes findings and purposes for the sustainability of the heritage corridor. The John H. Chafee Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor was established in 1986 to recognize its importance as the birthplace of the American Industrial Revolution. It serves as a model for cooperative efforts between the National Park Service and local communities to preserve historic sites and open spaces without federal ownership and regulations. The corridor is managed by a bi-state commission representing federal, state, and local authorities from Massachusetts. The John H. Chafee Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor, managed by authorities from Massachusetts and Rhode Island, faces the expiration of funding in November 2006. The National Park System Advisory Board will review the future of all national heritage areas. The Act aims to explore options for preserving the resources of the corridor and its sustaining partnerships. The John H. Chafee Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor, managed by Massachusetts and Rhode Island, is at risk of losing funding in November 2006. The National Park System Advisory Board will assess the future of all national heritage areas. The Act seeks to evaluate the sustainability of the corridor and provide recommendations for its future. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Corridor" refers to the John H. Chafee Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor. The term "Commission" refers to the John H. Chafee Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Commission. The term "Director" refers to the Director of the National Park Service. The Director will prepare a report on the sustainability of the John H. Chafee Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor, documenting progress in various areas and identifying further actions needed to protect and enhance the Corridor. The Director will prepare a report on the sustainability of the John H. Chafee Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor, evaluating federal funding, leveraging additional funds, assessing the management structure, and exploring options for a permanent designation. Coordination with the National Park System Advisory Board will be done, and the report will be submitted to Congress within a year. The Director will submit a report to Congress within a year, funded by annual appropriations for the Commission.
